0.title: Saudi Arabia Weighs Blaming Intelligence Official for Khashoggi Killing
0.abstract: Saudi rulers are considering blaming Gen. Ahmed al-Assiri, a deputy intelligence director who is close to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

1.title: Aide to Saudi Crown Prince, Suspect in Khashoggi Case, Is Shown Walking into Consulate
1.abstract: A photograph of the aide is one of the most striking pieces of evidence to date linking the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi to the crown prince.

2.title: Top Afghan Leaders Killed in Attack That Misses U.S. Commander
2.abstract: Among the dead in the attack claimed by the Taliban was Gen. Abdul Raziq, the powerful police chief of Kandahar. Three Americans were wounded.

3.title: U.S. Closing Jerusalem Consulate That Oversees Ties With Palestinians
3.abstract: The move is the latest blow to Palestinians after Washington recognized Jerusalem as Israel’s capital and relocated its embassy to the city.

4.title: Israel Can’t Deport U.S. Student Over Past Support for Boycott
4.abstract: Israel’s Supreme Court ordered the government to allow entry to Lara Alqasem, detained at the airport for more than two weeks while she fought deportation.

5.title: Religion and Women’s Rights Clash, Violently, at a Shrine in India
5.abstract: A New York Times journalist was met with rock-throwing and threats when she tried to visit a Hindu temple after justices ruled that women should be allowed access.

6.title: Theresa May Plays for Time on Brexit, Amid Talk of an Extension
6.abstract: At a summit Mrs. May asked for help in reviving stalled exit talks, but offered little new. Negotiations now look likely to go down to the wire.

7.title: Japan’s Cherry Blossoms (Some of Them) Appear Months Early
7.abstract: An unusually strong typhoon season may have caused the famously picturesque flowers to bloom long before April, when they typically emerge.

8.title: How One Journalist’s Death Provoked a Backlash That Thousands Dead in Yemen Did Not
8.abstract: The sudden turn against Saudi Arabia reveals uncomfortable realities of alliance politics, group psychology and the perception of morality.

9.title: The Times Talks Over Dinner
9.abstract: The Australia Letter brought readers together for food and conversation. There were many interesting insights. Now we’d like to hear from you.

10.title: Uighur Americans Speak Against China’s Internment Camps. Their Relatives Disappear.
10.abstract: Rushan Abbas, a Uighur American business consultant, hopes to get her sister and aunt freed from Chinese detention by swaying United States policy.

11.title: In Some Australian Schools, Teachers Can Be Fired for Being Gay
11.abstract: Australian politicians are doubling down on a law that allows religious schools, which receive government funding, to discriminate against gay teachers and students.

12.title: Vatican Mum on North Korea’s Invitation to Pope Francis
12.abstract: No pope has ever visited North Korea, although Francis has repeatedly called for reconciliation on the peninsula.

13.title: A New Culprit Is Identified in China’s Choking Smog
13.abstract: Researchers say that emissions of formaldehyde from autos and chemical and oil refineries play a larger role in China’s smog than previously known.

14.title: Jim Mattis, Meeting His Chinese Counterpart, Tries to Ease Tensions
14.abstract: The defense secretary moved to sand down sharp edges of the relationship after Vice President Mike Pence gave a pointed critique of Beijing.

15.title: Afghan Leader Blindsided by U.S. Meeting With Taliban, Officials Say
15.abstract: An American envoy who met the Taliban reportedly tried to evade the topic during a meeting with an already concerned Afghan president, several officials say.

16.title: Saudi Journalist, Midterms, DNA: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
16.abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

17.title: U.S. Bars American Aid Groups From Traveling to North Korea
17.abstract: The move comes as the Trump administration seeks to tighten sanctions as part of its maximum-pressure campaign during nuclear negotiations.

18.title: Overlooked No More: Yamei Kin, the Chinese Doctor Who Introduced Tofu to the West
18.abstract: Long before veggie burgers and soy lattes were fashionable, Kin was sent on a mission by the United States government to uncover the benefits of the soybean for Americans.

19.title: The Skywhale Returns to Australia’s Skies, and Its Creator Braces for Impact
19.abstract: The buxom hot-air balloon was widely condemned when it first appeared five years ago. The artist who created it is hoping for a warmer reception this time.

20.title: Ebola Outbreak in Congo Not a Global Emergency, W.H.O. Says
20.abstract: Health officials expressed serious concern about the disease, which has a high risk of spreading to neighbors, but were optimistic it would be controlled.

21.title: U.N. Syria Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, Announces Resignation
21.abstract: Mr. de Mistura, the United Nations chief negotiator for Syria, will be the third diplomat to leave the job since Syria’s grinding civil war began 7 years ago.

22.title: In Afghanistan’s Season of Crisis, ‘Words Do Not Have the Strength’
22.abstract: Seventeen years into the war, Afghans cannot remember a time quite like this, with peril and hopelessness at every turn, and no clear way out.

23.title: U.S. Spy Agencies Are Increasingly Convinced of Saudi Prince’s Ties to Journalist’s Disappearance
23.abstract: American intelligence officials have growing circumstantial evidence of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s involvement in Jamal Khashoggi’s disappearance in Istanbul.

24.title: The Legal Cannabis Experiment Begins: The Canada Letter
24.abstract: A special edition of the Canada Letter looks at the day marijuana became legal.

25.title: Brazil’s Bitter Presidential Race Leads to Scores of Assaults
25.abstract: The country is divided between a far-right candidate who advocates fighting violence with violence, and a leftist rival. The increasing animosity has led to more than 70 attacks on political opponents.

26.title: Audio Offers Gruesome Details of Jamal Khashoggi Killing, Turkish Official Says
26.abstract: The Saudi journalist’s fingers were severed and he was later beheaded, according to details from audio recordings published in the Turkish media.

27.title: A Top Indian Minister Resigns, but Can #MeToo Reform Government?
27.abstract: India’s governing party promised to champion women and economic growth, but more women are leaving the work force than ever, partly over safety concerns.

28.title: Istanbul Vending Machines Offer Subway Credit for Recycled Bottles and Cans
28.abstract: The city has installed “reverse vending machines” at metro stations that crush, shred and sort the materials as a way of paying for travel.

29.title: Queensland Becomes Latest Australian State to Decriminalize Abortion
29.abstract: After days of emotional debate, lawmakers overturned an 1899 law that made abortion a criminal offense. “History has been made,” the premier said.

30.title: Mother Mushroom, Vietnamese Activist, Is Said to Be Released
30.abstract: The blogger, whose real name is Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, was freed to fly to the U.S. as Defense Secretary Jim Mattis was visiting, rights groups said.

31.title: China Imposes Record Fine on Vaccine Maker Over Safety Scandal
31.abstract: The penalty, of $1.3 billion, comes at a time of increasing anxieties among the country’s middle class, already furious about a spate of drug and food safety scandals.

32.title: Student Gunman Kills 19 and Wounds Dozens at a College in Crimea
32.abstract: The lone attacker detonated an explosive device, then opened fire at his classmates, in the deadliest school assault in Russia since the Beslan massacre in 2004.

33.title: Mike Pompeo Meets Turkish President to Discuss Saudi Journalist’s Fate
33.abstract: President Trump said the United States had asked Turkish officials for what they say are recordings of the gruesome killing of Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents.

34.title: Legalizing Recreational Marijuana, Canada Begins a National Experiment
34.abstract: On Wednesday, Canada becomes the first major world economy to legalize recreational marijuana, presenting the country with enormous public policy challenges.

35.title: What’s at Stake in Brazil’s Election? The Future of the Amazon
35.abstract: The next president of Brazil may shape the destiny of the Amazon, which is vital to reining in climate change. The stakes for the planet are huge.

36.title: Ian Kiernan, Australian Sailor Who Battled Pollution, Dies at 78
36.abstract: Appalled by the trash he saw in the world’s oceans, he began a cleanup campaign in Sydney that went global.

37.title: Israel Strikes Gaza After a Rocket Is Fired
37.abstract: The main militant groups in Gaza, including Hamas and Islamic Jihad, issued a joint statement denying responsibility for the rocket fire against Israel.
